title-group.article-title: Effects of seawater immersion on water absorption and mechanical properties of GFRP composites

article-meta.aff: College of Aerospace and Materials Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, China

author-notes.corresp: Liping Bian, College of Aerospace and Materials Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China Email: bmoglp@126.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Water absorption behavior and mechanical properties of specimens of an epoxy resin casting and the glass fiber reinforced epoxy matrix composites (GFRP) with two fiber volume fractions (Vf) immersed into artificial seawater were investigated. The composite specimens absorbed less water than the resin casting because water absorption by the matrices was the main way in the composites. The composites with a Vf of 44% absorbed more water than the composites with a Vf of 34% because there were more micropores inside the fiber bundles and capillary paths in the higher fiber volume fractions. Due to the reversible and irreversible changes in the resin casting and the failure of the fiber/matrix interface, the tensile strength, the flexural strength, and the ILSS of the composite specimens after 42 days’ immersion decreased 13%, 43%, 50%, respectively. And the tensile strength, the flexural strength and the ILSS of the specimens after desorption were 97%, 38%, and 43% of the original state, respectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Glass fiber reinforced polymer (GFRP) composites are widely used in naval and submarine applications. The GFRP composites have good resistance to fatigue and corrosion, low maintenance cost, and their fitness for molding complex shapes without the need for machining. Also the design method, fabrication technology, and mechanical properties of composites have improved in recent years.1 The susceptibility to moisture of the GFRP composites and the change in properties when using them on marine applications are main concern problems.

Water absorption of the composites is a complex behavior, which can be influenced by many causes, such as the resin and cured agent, void content, properties of prepreg, fabrication, and so on.2–5 Many studies have been carried out on the immersion of GFRP composites in water or seawater bath. There are three ways of water absorption recognized widely.5–7 First, water molecules diffuse into the matrices. Second, the fiber/matrix interface capillarity effect speeds up diffusion of water molecules. Third, void and micro-cracks in composites store water and increase water absorption. The latter two are often damage-dependent. A damaged composite will absorb much more water. The damage, such as matrix cracks and interface debonding, is often a result of the exposure to a humid environment.

Water absorption speeds up evolution of damages inside composites and causes some novel damages. During water or seawater immersion test, many properties of the composites are altered because of changes in the matrix, the fiber, and the interface.5,8–13 The effects of water absorption on the mechanical properties of composites are mainly about the matrix plasticization and the interface debonding. The former is usually the reason for the decrease of strength of the composites, which could be recovered to the initial value after an appropriate desorption process, while the latter usually results in the irreversible decrease of the strength of the composites.

Many works showed the interlaminar shear strength (ILSS) and flexural strength degrading with increasing the contents of water absorption.8–11 Lassila et al.10 thought the matrix plasticization to be the main reason for the drop of flexural strength. The change of the flexural modulus of the composites after 140 to 210 days’ immersion was not significant.12 Some studies also showed that the Mode I interlaminar fracture toughness of GFRP composites was not significantly affected by seawater immersion11 and the Mode II interlaminar fracture toughness decreased due to the water absorption.3 And no obvious difference in fatigue life was found for the specimens aged in fresh and salt solution at room temperature in the previous study.13

In this article, E-glass fabric reinforcement epoxy resin composites with two fiber volume fractions (Vf) were fabricated by vacuum-assisted resin transfer molding (VARTM) to reduce the void content in the composites. Seawater immersion test was carried out for the composite specimens and edges of the specimen were not sealed. The objectives of this article were to study water absorption behavior of the composite materials with different fiber volume fractions and effects of seawater immersion on the mechanical properties.

sec.title: Raw materials and processing for the GFRP
sec.p:
The raw materials used in this study are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Raw materials and their manufacturers for experiment
Raw materials Trade name Manufacturer or supplier
Diglycidyl ether of bisphenol A CYD-128 Yueyang Epoxy Co.
Tetrahydrophthalic anhydride THPA Tianjin Jingdong Chemical Factory
2,4,6-tris(dimethylaminomethyl)phenol DMP-30 Shanghai SSS Reagnt Co.,Ltd.
E-glass fabrics E-glass damask fabrics Zigong Jiuda glass fiber Ltd.

Preparation of the resin casting specimens involves four steps. First, the epoxy resin, the curing agent and the accelerator are mixed according to the ratio of 100:70:0.7 (w/w) at 45°C. Then, air bubbles are removed from the mixture by vacuum. Third, the mixture is poured into molds to fabricate specimens for tensile, flexural properties tests, and immersion test. Fourth, the molds are heated in the oven at 85°C for 4 h and later at 120°C for 4 h, then cooled down to room temperature.

The composite specimen was manufactured by VARTM, whose flowchart is shown in Figure 1. The inject temperature was 45°C, and the heating program was the same as that for the resin casting preparation. Before injection, the mold was vacuumized and the system was kept at −0.1 MPa during the whole injection processing until no air bubbles appeared in the tube of extravasation. The thickness of the composite plates were about 3.5 mm. Figure 1.
The flow chart of VARTM process.

sec.title: Seawater immersion tests
sec.p: The seawater immersion tests of the resin casting specimens and the GFRP composite specimens were carried out based on Chinese Standard GB1462-88. The specimens were all molded or machined to plates. Sizes of the resin casting and the GFRP composites were 50 mm × 50 mm × 4 mm and 50 mm × 50 mm × 3.5 mm, respectively. For each specimen, five samples were prepared and tested under the same condition. All the specimens were dried in a oven at 50°C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. This process was repeated until the mass of the specimens change less than 0.1 mg. The dry specimens were immersed in a seawater bath at 30°C. The artificial seawater was made of tap water and sea salt in the ratio of 100:3.3. The seawater immersion test lasted for about 3 months. The specimens were regularly weighed at different intervals.

The moisture absorption was calculated by equation (1) with the mass gain of the samples (1)Mt(%)=mt-m0m0×100% where Mt is water mass gain, m0 and mt are the mass of the specimen before and during immersion, respectively.

sec.title: Mechanical tests
sec.p: The tensile and flexural properties of the resin casting were tested by the universal testing machine (UTM). In the tests, the cross-head speed was 2 mm/min. In the three-point bending test, the ratio of span to thickness of the specimen was 16:1. The specimens were classified into seven groups and each group had five samples. The first group included the original specimen without immersing before testing. The other five groups referred to the samples which were immersed into the artificial seawater at 30°C for 7, 11, 14, 21, 28 days, respectively, before testing. And the last group included the samples which were desorbed by putting the specimens in a glass desiccator at 35°C for 2 days after immersing into the artificial seawater for 28 days.

The tensile and flexural tests of the composite specimens were conducted according to the Chinese Standard GB 1447-2005 and GB1449-2005, respectively. In the tests, the cross-head speed was 2 mm/min. The ratio of span to thickness of the specimen was 16:1. The interlaminar shear strength (ILSS) measured by short beam shear test followed the Chinese Standard GB 3357-82. The length of the ILSS specimens was 28 mm, and the width was 6 mm. The ratio of span to thickness was about 5:1. The cross-head speed was 0.2 mm/min for the ILSS test.

Five groups of composite specimens (Vf = 44%) were used for mechanical properties test. Each group included 5 samples for tensile, flexural test and 10 samples for ILSS test. One group included dried samples, and three groups included the samples which were immersed into the artificial seawater at 30°C for 14, 28, 42 days, respectively, before testing. And another group included samples which were desorbed in desiccator at 35°C for 2 days after being immersed in the water for 42 days.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscope
sec.p: The scanning electron microscope (SEM), FEI Quanta 200, was used to observe the side surface of the composite materials. The ‘Image-pro Plus’ software was used to quantify the size and quantity of the micro pores in side surface images. Then the percentages of micropore on the surface of the composites were estimated by equations (2) and (3) (2)Ap=Amp+Afp (3)Ap=1Hl[A¯mphm(H-nhf)+nA¯mf] where Ap, Amp, Afp are the percentage of micropore on the side surface of the composites, matrices, and fabrics. A¯mp and A¯fp are the statistical date of area micropore of the matrix and the bundle of fabric; l is the length of the observed area on the image, hm, and hf are the height of the matrix and the bundle of fabric in the observed area. A¯mp, A¯fp, l, hm, and hf are calculated by the Image-pro software based on the SEM images. H and n are the height and the layers of the composite specimens, respectively.
The SEM was also used to observe tensile fracture section of the resin casting.

sec.title: (1) Fick’s law
sec.p: The water absorption behavior can be described quantitatively by Fick’s law, especially for the short time immersion tests.14,15 For 1-D moisture absorption, on both sides of the sample to the same environment, the equation can be simplified as the following (4)MtM∞=1-∑n=0∞8(2n+1)2π2exp[-D(2n+1)2π2th2] (5)D=π(kh4M∞)2

Where, M∞ is the saturation absorption, h is the thickness of the samples, and t is the immersion time and n is the summation index. D is the mass diffusivity coefficient and has the form of equation (5), where k is the initial slope of the plot of Mt versus t1/2.

sec.title: (2) Experimental results
sec.p:
Results of the seawater absorption of the resin casting and the composites with two fiber volume fractions are shown in Figure 2. According to Figure 2, the saturation absorption M∞ of the resin casting and the composites with Vf of 34% and 44% were 0.75%, 0.34%, and 0.44%, respectively. The mass diffusivity coefficient D of the specimens was calculated from equation (5) and Figure 2.The parameters k and D were all listed in Table 2. The value of D of the resin casting and the composites with Vf of 34% and 44% were 5.8 × 10−7mm2/s, 6.5 × 10−7mm2/s, and 7.7 × 10−7mm2/s, respectively. The values of Mt according to Fick’s law, were gained by taking M∞ and D into equation (4) and the simulated data were described with the solid black line in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Seawater absorption curves for the resin casting and the composites with different Vf. Table 2.
Parameters of water absorption behavior of the resin casting and the two composites with different Vf
Composites
Resin casting Vf = 34% Vf = 44%
Saturation absorption M∞ (%) 0.75 0.34 0.44
The slope k (×10−6s−1/2) 3.2 1.7 2.5
The thickness h (mm) 4.0 3.5 3.5
Mass diffusivity coefficient D (×10−7mm2/s) 5.8 6.5 7.7

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As shown in Figure 2 and Table 2, both the resin casting and the composites specimens had a low mass gain during the immersion test. The epoxy resin casting and the E-glass fabric reinforced composites were low water absorption materials. By comparing the experimental data with the simulated ones according to the Fick’s law in Figure 2, the water absorption behavior of the resin casting can be described by Fick’s law accurately. Although, there was a little difference between the experimental data and simulated data of the composite materials. At the beginning of the immersion, the experimental data were a lower than that estimated by Fick’s law. As the immersion time increased, the experimental data were slightly bigger than the simulated ones. These results were mainly because of the integrative effects of the matrix, micropores, and interface between fiber/matrix. And as the immersion time increased, water absorption behavior became complex as discussed below.

sec.title: (1) Fabrics block effects
sec.p: Water absorption behavior of the composites was more complex than that of the resin casting. Although the interfaces of the composite were vulnerable to water absorption, during the early stage of the test, water molecules only diffused into the surface of the composites, and the fabric may block the diffusion or prolong the diffusion path. So the matrices in the GFRP absorbed less water than the resin casting plates at the early time during the immersion test. Gellert et al.12 used the physical barrier effects of the fabric to explain the experiment results. As the time increased, there would be other ways to speed up the water absorption, such as the capillarity of the interface and water storage in void.

sec.title: (2) Matrix-dominated mechanism
sec.p: As shown in Table 2, the parameter M∞ for the composites were even lower than that for the resin casting. This result was partly as same as the results of the experimentally described by Lassila et al.10 During the short time immersion test, the water absorption by the glass fabric was neglected compared to the matrix.16 The composites had less resins compared the pure resin specimens in the same size. Their results showed that the composites also absorbed less water than the resin casting. We believe that the water absorption of the GFRP investigated in this article belongs to the so-called ‘matrix –dominated’ mechanism, which was proposed by Pavlidou et al.17 Effects of interface treatments of glass fiber on water absorption behavior was studied. They observed that the composites with glass fiber treated by silane had smaller water mass gain in water immersion test than that of a clean or by a PDMS-treated GFRP. The former had a higher ILSS than the latter two. The results indicate that for the silane-treated composite, it is the matrix that absorbs moisture, whereas for the other two composites, the weak interface speed up the water absorption and it called as the ‘interface-dominated’ mechanism.The E-glass fabrics used in this study were also treated by silane. According to the mechanical results of the composite specimens, as shown in Table 6, the ILSS of the composites with two different Vf were about 55 MPa, and the ILSS of silane-treated E-glass fabrics reinforced unsaturated polyester composites in the study of Pavlidou et al.17 was about 27 MPa. Compared to the ILSS results, the interface in this study was better, so the water absorption for the composites in this study was also considered as ‘matrix-dominated’ mechanism.

sec.title: (3) Void-accelerated mechanism
sec.p:
As the immersion time increased, the interface became weaker and water diffused into inner composite by the matrix/fabric interface capillary paths and then stored in the pores. This process accelerated the water absorption by leading more water molecules to penetrate into the inner composites. There were few macropores in the composites fabricated by VARTM process in this study. However, many micropores distributed uniformly in the composites can be observed as shown in Figure 3. The micropores supplied the extra space to store water, so the experimental data of mass gain of the fabricated composite samples were higher than those of the simulated data obtained by Fick’s law. Figure 3.
Side surface SEM images of the composite specimen before immersion test: (a) matrix (2000X); (b) fabric (2000X); (c) Vf = 34% (200X); (d) Vf = 44%(200X).

The statistical areas of the micropores of the matrix and the bundle of fabric on the side surface were gained from Figure 3(a) and (b) and listed in Table 3. The average size of the micropores in the matrixes was smaller than that in the bundle of fabric, especially in the matrix/fiber interface. It can be concluded that the composites with more fabric may have more micropores at a certain extent of fiber volume fraction. The SEM images of side surface of the two composites with different fiber volume fraction are shown in Figure 3(c) and (d). And the percentage of micropore area in the side surface were estimated and listed in Table 4. The composites with a Vf of 44% had more micropores and interfaces, so the ‘void-accelerated’ mechanism was more obvious in the immersion test, which resulted in the larger mass gain and mass diffusivity coefficient than those of the composites with Vf of 34%. Table 3.
Statistical data of the micro pores on matrices and the bundle of fabric
Matrix Fabric
Measurement range (µm) 150 × 130 150 × 91
Min area (µm2) 0.2150 0.2150
Max area (µm2) 31.1506 59.7644
Sum area (µm2) 765.8655 872.1730
Mean area (µm2) 0.7752 1.9956
Std. dev 1.34 4.49
Samples 988 446
Table 4.
Compute results for the percentages of micro pores on the side surface of the composites
Vf (%) Length (mm) Height (mm) Layers Side surface area micropore percentages (%)
34 50 3.5 15 4.89%
44 50 3.5 19 5.15%

sec.title: Evolution of the mechanical properties for the resin casting during immersion
sec.p:
Tensile strength, flexural strength, and modulus of the resin casting specimens are given in Table 5. Both the tensile and the flexural strengths of the samples immersed had dramatic decrease with a similar trend. Table 5.
Tensile and flexural properties of the cast resin after immerging various times
Immersion time Tensile Flexural
σ¯ (MPa) Cv (%) Drop degree (%) E¯ (GPa) Cv (%) σ¯ (MPa) Cv (%) Drop degree (%) E¯ (GPa) Cv (%)
Original 82 7 0 3.4 6 136 7 0 3.4 3
7 days 74 14 10 3.1 3 109 10 20 3.1 3
11days 63 19 23 3.0 3 111 19 20 3.2 6
14 days 44 34 46 3.2 3 76 18 44 3.4 3
21 days 31 39 62 3.0 3 59 17 57 3.2 3
28 days 27 63 67 2.3 9 41 41 70 3.3 3
Desorption 75 17 10 3.0 7 118 17 13 3.2 6
σ¯ stands for the average strength, E¯ stands for the average modulus, Cv stands for the coefficient of variation.

After immersion for 1 month, the tensile strength decreased from 82 MPa to 27 MPa and the flexural strength decreased from 136 MPa to 41 MPa. The tensile modulus decreased from 3.4 GPa to 2.3 GPa and the flexural modulus from 3.4 GPa to 3.0 GPa. The tensile strength and modulus of the samples after desorption were 75 MPa and 3.0 GPa, respectively. And the flexural strength and modulus of the samples after desorption were 118 MPa and 3.2 GPa, respectively. Both the tensile and flexural strengths recover beyond 85% of the original specimens. However, after immersion, the coefficients of variation of the tensile strength increased from 7% to 63%, and the coefficient of variation of the flexural strength increased from 7% to 41%. Both the coefficients of variation of the tensile and flexural strength of the samples after desorption were 17%.

Considering the results of mechanical properties at immersion state and desorption state, it can be indicated that there are reversible and irreversible changes in the epoxy resin matrix during the immersion. Water molecules entering the network of matrix accelerate matrix cracking which lead to decrease of the tensile and flexural strength.13 In the early time of the immersion test, water molecules diffused into the spaces between polymer chains and occupied positions between the chains. Water molecules acted as a plasticizer and the polymer chains generally became more mobile and the tensile and flexural modulus decreased. After the desorption process, this part of water would be volatilized, and mechanical properties of the samples can be recovered.10,14,18,19 As the immersion time increased, the interaction between water and epoxy resins became more complex. The water existed as a viable resin/water-binding complex and promoted secondary cross linking with hydrophilic groups in epoxy resin (such as hydroxyls and amines)or the water molecules stayed in the micropores even causing the microcracks. These parts of water were usually difficult to desorb and the changes would be thought as irreversible.18,19 So after the desorption process the tensile and flexural strength of the samples only recovered partly.

Due to the water–epoxy resin interactions, especially in the late time of immersion, the second cross linking with hydrophilic groups, the polar groups in the epoxy resin was increased and the resin became more brittle gradually. Figure 4 shows the tensile test curves of the resin casting and Figure 5 shows the flexural test curves of the resin casting. The curve gained from the original state is obviously more curviform than that from the immersion states. And the curves of the samples after 7 days’ immersion were more curviform than that of the samples after 1 month immersion. This indicated that although the immersion had the plastification effect for a resin casting, under some conditions, the final effect was to make the resin casting become brittle. Figure 6 shows the tensile fractographs of the resin matrix; it was noticeable that the resin casting after immersion became more brittle than that of the original. The fracture surface for day samples of the resin casting (Figure 6(a)) was much rougher than that for the samples after immersion (Figure 6(b)). This suggested that before immersion the matrices can absorb more break energy under loading. Figure 4.
Curves of tensile stress vs strain for the resin casting. Figure 5.
Curves of the stress vs displacement of the resin casting under bending. Figure 6.
Tensile fractographs SEM of the resin casting specimens: (a) virgin (500X); (b) after 28 days’ immersion (500X).

sec.title: Evolution of the mechanical properties for the composites during immersion
sec.p:
Mechanical properties of the dry samples of the GFRP composites with Vf of 34% and 44% are listed in Table 6. They can be considered as the references while researching the effects of immersion time on the properties. Table 6.
Mechanical properties of the composites with two fiber volume fraction
Tensile Flexural ILSS
Vf (%) σ¯ (MPa) Cv (%) E¯ (GPa) Cv (%) σ¯ (MPa) Cv (%) E¯ (GPa) Cv (%) σ¯ (MPa) Cv (%)
34 387 2 16.0 5 454 2 16.4 2 54 2
44 493 4 19.6 3 487 3 21.0 2 56 4

The mechanical properties of the composites with higher fiber volume fraction were obviously higher. And as shown in Table 2, the composites with Vf of 44% absorbed more water. The composites with Vf of 44% was chosen as a candidate to investigate the effects of water absorption on mechanical properties.

Table 7 lists the mechanical properties of the composites specimens with a Vf of 44% at different states. After 14 days, the tensile strength, the flexural strength, and the ILSS dropped by 7%, 20%, and 46%, respectively. And 28 days later, the tensile strength, the flexural strength, and the ILSS dropped by 10%, 38%, and 50%, respectively. Then 42 days later, the tensile strength, the flexural strength, and the ILSS dropped by 13%, 43%, and 50%, respectively. Table 7.
Tensile and flexural properties and ILSS of the GRP composites after immerging various times along with the desorption samples
Immersion time Tensile Flexural ILSS
σ¯ (MPa) Cv (%) Drop degree (%) E¯ (GPa) Cv (%) σ¯ (MPa) Cv (%) Drop degree (%) E¯ (GPa) Cv (%) σ¯ (MPa) Cv (%) Drop degree (%)
Original 493 4 0 19.6 3 487 3 0 21.0 2 54 4 0
14 days 460 3 7 20.3 2 389 3 20 21.1 2 29 6 46
28 days 442 3 10 19.6 3 300 3 38 22.5 1 27 6 50
42 days 429 3 13 18.5 2 278 2 43 18.8 1 26 3 50
Desorption 479 4 3 20.4 3 304 4 38 19.5 4 31 6 43

The dropping rate and dropping degree of the ILSS were the maximum, and those of the flexural strength were moderate, while those of the tensile strength were the smallest. The differences were also presented in the desorption states. The tensile strength was about 97% of the original state. The flexural strength was about 62% of the original state. But the ILSS had few changes compared with the immersed specimens. The tensile and flexural modulus of the composites had no significant decrease. The coefficient of variation of ILSS of the samples after immersion decreased from 4% to 6%.

In the short time seawater immersion test, there are two main reasons which lead to mechanical properties to decline gradually. One is the decreased on the mechanical properties of the matrices. The other is the debonding of the fiber/matrix interface, which is an irreversible change and directly cause the degrading the interface strength. Comparing Figure 3(b) with Figure 7, the void of interface became slightly bigger, especially in the interlayer of the fabric after the immersion. Figure 7.
Side surface SEM image of the composite specimen after 42 days’ immersion (2000X).

As shown in Figure 8 and Table 7, after immersion the decrease in tensile strength was less. After drying, the tensile strength of the composites recovers with the extent of 97% of the original state. These results were mainly because the tensile strength was sensitive to the fiber strength and the properties of the fiber had changed little during the short time immersion test. Figure 8.
Curves of tensile stress vs strain curves of the composites specimens under tension.

As shown in Figure 9, the flexural strength dropped quickly at the first month during the immersion test. In the three-point bending state, the composite specimens not only bear the tensile and press stress at the lower and upper part, but also bear the shear stress on the middle plan. The flexural strength of the composite is sensitive to the fiber strength and ILSS. After drying, the properties only had a partial reversion because of the irreversibly failure of the interface. Figure 9.
The flexural stress vs displacement curves of the composites specimens under bending.

Figure 10 only showed the curves of interlaminar shear stress versus displacement of the composite specimens of the original state and immersion state. After 14 days immersion, the ILSS dropped dramatically, and then underwent few changes with immersion time. The specimens at desorption state also had little change. The ILSS is sensitive to the adhesive strength of the interface between the fiber and the matrix. The debonding of interface directly lead to the decrease of ILSS. Figure 10.
The interlaminar shear stress vs displacement curves of the composites specimens under short beam bending.

Gellert’s work12 showed that the flexural strength of the GFRP composites only decreased by 9–36% after immersion in water bath at 30°C for 120 days or 210 days. Compared to those results, the flexural strength of the GFRP composites decreased greatly in this study. Since the edges of the specimens were sealed in that test the water absorption along the interface can be neglected, the breakages of the interface were smaller in that study than in study whose edges of the specimens were directly exposed in seawater without any protection. The comparison between the two cases suggested that the interface had a significant effect on the water absorption behavior and mechanical properties of the composites.

list-item.p: The mechanism of so-called ‘matrix-dominated’ resulted in saturation absorption; M∞ of the resin casting was higher than that of the composites. And the mechanism of so-called ‘void-accelerated’ mechanism resulted in mass diffusivity coefficient D of the composites with Vf of 44% being the biggest and that of the resin casting being the smallest.

The reversible and irreversible changes between the epoxy resin and water molecule lead to the tensile and flexural strength of the resin casting dropped in immersion state, and partly recover after drying. Tensile fractographs indicated that the resin casting became more brittle in immersion state.

The tensile strength, the flexural strength, and the ILSS of the composite specimens after 42 days’ immersion had decreased by 13%, 43%, and 50%, respectively. Because of the debonding of the interface and the reversible and irreversible changes in the mechanical properties of the matrix after immersion, the tensile strength, the flexural strength, and the ILSS of the composites after desorption recovered about 97%, 38%, and 43% of the original state, respectively.
After short time immersion, the modulus of the specimens had no significant changes. The coefficient of variation of ILSS of the composites after immersion increased from 4% to 6%.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: This paper has no conflict of interest.
